section.title: Exericse: Eclipse user creation and Gerrit server configuration
Create an Eclipse user account
section.para:
To contribute to an Eclipse project you need to have valid user credentials. If you already have an Eclipse Bugzilla or Eclipse Forum account, you have already done this step. These systems use the same account.
You can create a new user via the following:
Create Eclipse.org user account
.

section.title: Sign the Contributor License Agreement (CLA)
section.para: You also need to confirm to the Eclipse foundation that you have the right to contribute your code to the Eclipse open source project. This requires that you sign a contributor license agreement (CLA) via a web interface. Signing is really simple and only takes a few minutes.
The Eclipse CLA FAQ describes the process and purpose of the CLA. At the end this document contains a link for signing the CLA. You find it under the following URL: Eclipse CLA FAQ .

tip.para: In case you contribute to the Eclipse open source project during your work time, ensure that your employer agrees that the code can be contributed.

section.title: Configure your Eclipse Gerrit user
section.para: You need to configure Gerrit if you want to use SSH or HTTPS to upload your contributions. The Gerrit user is NOT the same as your Eclipse user. Also, the Gerrit HTTPS password is NOT the same as your Eclipse user password.
To configure your access method open the following URL: Gerrit at Eclipse and login with your Eclipse account (registered email address) and password via the top right corner of your browser.
Afterwards select Settings as highlighted in the following screenshot.

You can either use SSH or HTTPS to push to Gerrit. See
for the configuration of HTTPS and
for the configuration of the SSH access. If you are not familiar with SSH, the HTTPS authentication is most likely easier to configure for you. If your company is using a proxy, you may have to use HTTPS as some proxies block SSH.

section.title: Authentication via HTTPS
section.para: The web page of the Gerrit review system enables you to generate an HTTP password. Select the HTTP password in the Gerrit user settings and generate a password. This setting is depicted in the following screenshot (the password is obfuscated).

Take note or copy the password, as it will be needed to push your changes to the Eclipse Gerrit system. In contrast to SSH, when using HTTPS you will have to enter your password for each operation with Gerrit. You can visit this page later if you forgot the password.

section.title: Authentication via SSH
section.para: You need to upload your SSH key to the Gerrit installation so that you can push changes to Gerrit via SSH. Once you have created a SSH key pair, upload your public SSH key to Gerrit to be able to push to it.
